Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes

Author: CryptoNinjaa#5350
Content: "Monetize your data feeds and existing APIs by selling them directly to smart contracts."

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c so I would need to 51% attack to force other nodes to think my fake prices were correct?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well it might be ugly, but it is the first trustless pricefeed that i know of

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can mine all the blocks, as soon as you mine an invalid price the rest of nodes will reject it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c i was saying that your graphs were pretty, sorry that was not clear

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how can you get nodes to accept a price that doesnt match all the nodes local prices?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this price feed stuff needs DPoW to be safe, it seems

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if ( minedprice not within 1% localprice) reject block

Author: Markus#5464
Content: what is the meaning of trace 0 to 3?

Author: Markus#5464
Content: what do they stand for

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 0 is the mined prices

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 1 is the correlated price to eliminate the 2% price change attack

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c what if I have 99% nethash and censor blocks from all other miners, and slowly ramp up 1% constantly?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 2 is the prev 24hr average

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 3 is 2 shifted back a day

Author: Markus#5464
Content: Alright

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can have 100% of hashrate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as soon as the price you mine is more than 1% away from the local price, the node will reject it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: think of it like timestamps

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is using essentially the same mechanism

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can submit a timestamp a bit in the future, a bit more from the past, but it needs to be reasonable or it will get rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so like a timestamp that is more than a minute from the future relative to system clock is rejected, a price that is more than 1% from local prices is rejected

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: doesnt matter the hashrate, baked into the consensus

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c what if I DoS all other nodes off the network, only leaving attacker nodes that all agree on prices?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but this +/-1% allows a 2% attack. ie,bias the price +1% and then bias the price -1%, for a 2% swing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then it wont get notarized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and you are welcome to have a private chain with bogus prices, but how do you "double spend" or in this case make a bet payout when it shouldnt

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: line 1 is a deterministic random data point from the prior day that has 51% correlation with the following data points

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so this makes the 2% attack require 100% control over 2 days to conduct

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: still possible, but much harder to control

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: very fascinating stuff, i am sure this will interest some chains that want to do oracle-y stuff, maybe to migrate to an asset chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i added -ac_prices=crypto, .... and -ac_stocks=stock, .... options to use the standard data source for binance cryptos and iex stocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but a small source code fork and any data source can be used by an assetchain to make a trustless oracle from that data source

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are also the 32 forex currencies tracked by ECB

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and once you have a trustless data source...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can have CC use it as inputs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: interesting, so much potential

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, and i defined 2 new CC building on this that i think people will like a lot, especially traders

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not minute by minute day traders though, as the pricefeed is trustless but a day delayed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we will be looking for beta testers who are experienced traders and can do unix commandline

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: @jl777c is this oracle up for testing? this is what we need for what I call 'grenades' -- i.e contracts that perform specific trading operations automatically and transparently....

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a blockchain, the trustless oracles use coinbase for the pricefeed

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: so how would an -ac chain like LUMBER pull the data from the oracle?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: -ac_cbopret=7 -ac_prices="ETH, LINK" -ac_stock="AAPL, GOOG"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that would gather the basic prices plus ETH, LINK, AAPL and GOOG

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then using prices rpc call you can get the most recent prices

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i will add a getprice rpc call to get the price for any pricefeed as of any block

Author: Lumbi#8378
Content: is fiat USD, EUR, etc also to be found the same way? -ac_cbopret=7 ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the ECB currencies are part of the basic prices, along with BTC and KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://www.ecb.europa.eu/stats/policy_and_exchange_rates/euro_reference_exchange_rates/html/index.en.html
